raw_text: We follow Kruengkrai et al (2009) and split the CTB 5 into training, development testing and testing sets, as shown in Table 3
clean_text: We follow Kruengkrai et al (2009) and split the CTB 5 into training, development testing and testing sets, as shown in Table 3.

raw_text: Kruengkrai et al (2009) made use of character type knowledge for spaces, numerals, symbols, alphabets, Chinese and other characters
clean_text: Kruengkrai et al (2009) made use of character type knowledge for spaces, numerals, symbols, alphabets, Chinese and other characters.

raw_text: Kruengkrai et al (2009) and Zhang and Clark (2008) are the most similar to our system among related work
clean_text: Kruengkrai et al (2009) and Zhang and Clark (2008) are the most similar to our system among related work.

raw_text: Thework of Kruengkrai et al (2009) is based on Nakagawa and Uchimoto (2007), which separates the processing of known words and unknown words, and uses a set of segmentation tags to represent the segmentation of characters
clean_text: The work of Kruengkrai et al (2009) is based on Nakagawa and Uchimoto (2007), which separates the processing of known words and unknown words, and uses a set of segmentation tags to represent the segmentation of characters.

raw_text: Our learning and decoding algorithms are also different from Kruengkrai et al (2009)
clean_text: Our learning and decoding algorithms are also different from Kruengkrai et al (2009).

Therefore, it? s natural that we evaluate the accuracy of joint Chinese word segmentation and part of speech tagging, as reported in previous literature (Kruengkrai et al 2009)
clean_text: Therefore, it's natural that we evaluate the accuracy of joint Chinese word segmentation and part of speech tagging, as reported in previous literature (Kruengkrai et al 2009).

raw_text: For ordinary word segmentation, the best result is reported to be around 97% F1 on CTB 5.0 (Kruengkrai et al, 2009), while our parser performs at 97.3%, though we should rem em ber that the result concerns flat words only
clean_text: For ordinary word segmentation, the best result is reported to be around 97% F1 on CTB 5.0 (Kruengkrai et al, 2009), while our parser performs at 97.3%, though we should remember that the result concerns flat words only.

citing_paper_authors: Jun, Hatori | Takuya, Matsuzaki | Yusuke, Miyao | Jun'ichi, Tsujii
raw_text: Because the tasks of word segmentation and POS tagging have strong interactions, many studies have been devoted to the task of joint word segmentation and POS tagging for languages such as Chinese (e.g. Kruengkrai et al (2009))
clean_text: Because the tasks of word segmentation and POS tagging have strong interactions, many studies have been devoted to the task of joint word segmentation and POS tagging for languages such as Chinese (e.g. Kruengkrai et al (2009)).

clean_text: "Kruengkrai+ '09" is a lattice-based model by Kruengkrai et al (2009).

raw_text: We applied morphological analysis and part-of-speech tagging by using TreeTagger (Schmid, 1994) for English, JUMAN for Japanese, and mma (Kruengkrai et al, 2009) for Chinese, respectively
clean_text: We applied morphological analysis and part-of-speech tagging by using TreeTagger (Schmid, 1994) for English, JUMAN for Japanese, and mma (Kruengkrai et al, 2009) for Chinese, respectively.

citing_paper_authors: Wenliang, Chen | Min, Zhang | Haizhou, Li
raw_text: We used the MMA system (Kruengkrai et al, 2009) trained on the training data to perform word segmentation and POS tagging and used the Baseline parser to parse all the sentences in the data
clean_text: We used the MMA system (Kruengkrai et al, 2009) trained on the training data to perform word segmentation and POS tagging and used the Baseline parser to parse all the sentences in the data.

raw_text: Firstly, the Chinese sentences are segmented, POS tagged and parsed by the tools described in Kruengkrai et al (2009) and Cao et al (2007), both of which are trained on the Penn Chinese Treebank 6.0
clean_text: Firstly, the Chinese sentences are segmented, POS tagged and parsed by the tools described in Kruengkrai et al (2009) and Cao et al (2007), both of which are trained on the Penn Chinese Treebank 6.0.

clean_text: On the Chinese side, we used the morphological analyzer described in (Kruengkrai et al, 2009) trained on the training data of CTBtp to perform word segmentation and POS tagging and used the first-order Parsers to parse all the sentences in the data.
